content.description:
This is a mixed trad/sport route. You can see the first bolt from the base of the first pitch, but looks like you'd need a trad placement to avoid a bad groundfall if you fell before the first bolt.

Another option is to do the first pitch of Safari, then rappel to the anchor at the top of pitch 1, then climb pitch 2 and 3. On pitch 2, if you get to a bolt with a rappel ring you passed the second anchor.

I didn't see a anchor at the top of this pitch but may have missed it. be ready to build a trad anchor at the top and then walk off bushwhacking climber's right until intersecting the walkoff trail a the top of first tier.
content.protection: Mixed trad/bolt. Bolted Anchors at the top of Pitch 1 & 2.
content.location: Go left/up when you intersect the wall from the approach trail. It is right of Safari. There is a tree at the base.

content.description: Up to a ledge to the first bolt. Continuous moves past the next several bolts then eases off to the anchor.
content.location: This is the first route at the base of the first tier as your hiking up the trail.

content.description:
After reaching first tier, take the vertical handline up, traverse right to the horizontal handlines. Where the first line meets the second line, you'll find this route. Another 5.8 slab. mid-route there's a nice section without handholds which is the crux. Use some palm-presses and trust your feet to get through.

Route is 140 feet. There is an intermediate rappel station to the left of the route. Bypass it on your way up, but use it to descend the route in two rappels with a 60m rope
content.protection: bolted. two anchor bolts with rap rings

content.description: Scramble up grassy ledges past a bolt keeping to the right. Clip the next bolt and game on. Continuous climbing on nice edges and slab to the anchor. 2 raps off with a 60 meter rope.
content.location: Right below the headwall, follows the grey runoff streak on the right. Rap station about 40' up the route.

content.description:
A bolted slabby pitch, starting to the left side of the horizontal handline.

When arriving at first tier, continue right until reaching the vertical handline. Climb the handline to a ledge which continues right.. You will reach a horizontal handline. this is where the climb starts.

The climb is shown as mixed, however one can do the route just with the bolts if comfortable at the grade. There is a finger-sized cam placement between two of the furthest bolts.
content.protection: Bolted anchors with rings. Bolts up the route, but can use an optional finger-sized cam.

content.description: Safari is a bolted slab 5.8 route at the far left side of the first tier.
content.location: At the left side of the main wall. When the approach trail comes to the wall, head left and follow the wall up. You'll see a line of bolts at what appears to be the left-most portion of the wall, with a very large steep rock just to the left of it.

content.description:
P-1 90'  5.8 Moderate climbing through the lower half, then starts to increase up to the last bolt where the crux is. Move up and left to the anchor.

P-2 90'  5.8  More bolts to an anchor
content.location: Wandering bolt line to the left of Daisies.

content.description:
A fun first pitch off the ground protected by bolts sets you up to breach the only easy way thru the short, steep Headwall.

Makes for a great way to approach harder climbing higher up the mountain.

The knotted hand line at the base of First Tier is key to finding the start. From atop the hand line, the first two lines of bolts to the right is correct. The left most line is unnamed at the moment, and to the right is the shared start of Cool Cat and OJ. Cool Cat heads up and slightly right, while OJ trends hard left, traversing above the roof and into the slab above.

P1  90' 5.8 ~9bolts.

P2  85' 5.10 bolts and a rack of singles to 3".  Lower off chains are visible from the belay. Don't hang out and belay from their uncomfortable location, there is another pair of bolts atop the Headwall if you're continuing higher.

P-1 5.8  Place a cam (# 2 or 3) before the first bolt. Clip the first bolt and move right. After several more bolts is a crack for small cams, then bolts to the roof anchor.

P-2 5.10b  Step around the corner to 2 bolts on a short steep panel. This is the crux followed by several cams and bolts to the anchor. A 60 meter rope reaches some grassy ledges to walk off.
content.location: 50 feet right of Doofus. Line of bolts trending right towards the roof.

content.description:
This is a two pitch slab climb on the right side of the first tier.

The 5.9 crux is between the first and second bolt, where you will have to do a mantle through a glass-polished section with a hand-foot match. You may be tempted to bypass to the right but that is loose/chossy and looks like a feasible path but isn't. By the time you realize this you'll be far enough from the bolt that peeling off puts you at ground-fall risk. After this move the remainder of the first pitch is 5.8ish and the second pitch is 5.7.

The intermediate belay is a marginal stance and you may want to skip it and link pitches. Weigh that decision against the rope drag, as the route bends right after this anchor and there will be moderate rope drag to the second achors.

Descend in two raps with a 60M rope.
content.protection: Bolted. Both anchors have two bolts with rap rings.
content.location: Take the vertical handline up, traverse right on the ledge.. pass the handlines. You'll see a scramble that heads up through some grass to the wall.

content.description:
P-1 5.8 80'Start in the same crack as Breakfast and continue angling right past bolts. Higher a crack accepts cams then move left on a ramp to the anchor. Or continue to the right to a higher anchor at 98'.

P-2 5.7 60' PG From the higher right anchor follow a crack system on easy ground. At some point the crack gets wide and there is no pro, but easy climbing. Higher is two bolts leading to the second anchor of Daisies.
content.protection: single rack thru 3", wires, several bolts per pitch

content.description:
P-1 90' 5.9 Continuous moves in the 5.8 range until a crux move to the left is encountered. More 5.8 after that.

P-2 90' 5.8 Follow bolts to the next anchor.

P-3 90' 5.8 Look for a crack in a lt. facing dihedral which leads to the top. Head right to the bolt anchors on top of the headwall. 3 raps from here gets to the trail.
content.protection: about 10 bolts, small to med cams for P-3
content.location: Last route on the right before the handline to the headwall section.

content.description:
P-1 5.7 90'  A series of easy ledges leads to the second bolt and the short crux. Trend left to the anchor.

P-2 5.10a 90' Pull a small roof above the anchor (crux) and continue thru some cool climbing to the anchor ledge. Rap the route.
content.location: This is the left side route below the headwall and gains the ledge at the base of the headwall routes.

content.description:
P-1 5.9 140' A left facing dihedral to the right of Seriously is filled with plenty of grass but has some nice crack sections. Higher up move left onto the last several bolts of Seriously. Pro to 4"        An alternative is to climb Seriously.

P-2 5.10c 90' From the anchor move right on a ramp and into a recess capped with a roof. Pull the roof and continue through a series of cracks towards the left facing hanging dihedral. Several bolts get you through this and to the anchor. Pro: single rack to 3", wires.  Lower back to the headwall ledge
content.location:
To the right of the headwall is a steep broken area leading to the lt. facing dihedral up higher.

This is a sustained climb with wild exposure.

content.description: Scramble thru grassy ledges to the base of the arch. Stem and jam this to its end where you can either continue up and right past 2 bolts (PG), or move left past 4 bolts to the second anchor of Daises.
content.location: Climb up the fixed hand line and belay there. The obvious arch is to the left.

content.description: Start in a crack for about 20' then angle left onto face to bolts and the shared anchor with Leap Day.
content.location: 15' right of Leap Day, the obvious crack.

content.description: The difficulty begins at the second bolt with the crux at the third bolt. Past that it gets easier.
content.location: The second route to the right as you get to the first tier.
